ANNEMARTIN, FAMOUS WOMAN.
SUFFRAGIST, EXPLAINS WHY
THEHUNGER STRIKE IN CAPITAL

Miss vice
chairman of the National
party and chairman of its legislative
committee spoke before an attentive
audience at the Maids’ and Matrons’
club rooms at $ o’cleck this after
noon

Among the many points covered by
Miss Martin in her speech was picket-
Anne Martin of Reno,
ing in Washington and why the women |

consider this an effective means of
bringing about the desired aims of the
suffragists. She said:

“In answer to the questions ‘Have
the pickets done any gvuod’ and ‘Do you
think you are gaining anything by
picketing?’ I have to say that 1 know
the pickets have done good. I know
that woman suffrage would be a lost
and forgotten issue in this time of war
if it had not been for the pickets. The
pickets have kept the subject of suf-
frage before the people—and the presi-
dent, There mav have been other
ways in which that could have been
the District of Columbia. There could

Women’s|be no law against it as the right of|
peaceful petition is guaranteed by the; for Ayer, Mass., where she will visit |
the
pickets the adminieiguan and the cap- |
constitution In order to arrest
'tain of the District police appointed by
the administration have had to trump

up the repeatedly disproved charge of
“obstructing traffic.”
Miss Martin also said:
Paul began her hunger strike because

she and her comrades, for demanding
better air in the district jail, were put
in small 5 by 7 cells in solitary confine
ment without air and denied the right

to buy their own food. to have ho
and newspapers and to see thelr
friznds. These privileges art i =

other prisoners in jail, including seve
teen murderers. When the suffra gi \
political prisoners are given the same

rights as other prisoners, Miss Paul
states, the hunger strike will close
“Forcible feeding is a practice con
demned by reputable physician

done. Picketing was the most effective cruel and as making the health of the
way we could discover. We have gain- prisoner worse; really a method of te!
ed 40 votes in congress since picket- rorizing prisoners. Miss Paul did nol
ing began in January accept food voluntarily, but the t u
“Delegations and rolls of petitions were forced in her mouth and she wa
to the White House had failed, pick- physically overpowered and fed the
eting offered a dramatic and constant statement of the jail physician notwith
appeal. There is no law against it in’ standing.”

IN CATHOLIC CIRCLES

The generosity cf the business men
of Ogden has been displayed and
greatly appreciated by) Catholic
women of the Red Cress. J Lewis
donated two rooms in the Lewis build-
ing on Washington avenue, where they
will hold all meetings pertaining to}
the work they are performing. E. F.
Hundley, manager of the Ogden Fur-
niture & Carpet company, furnished
the chairs. L. J. Healy, representative |
of the White Sewing Machine com-
pany, supplied two of the machines,
and Dr. Margaret Burns offered to z
|

nish a sewing machine and a large
tablet. The unit will hold a meeting
each week on Tuesday afternoon and
all the Catholic women who are inter
ested in the work are requested to at
tend,

Mark Crites, spent several days in Po. |

an’s daughter, Mrs. John Dulton.

MARTHA SOCIETY

The Martha ociety tenth annual
ball will be given in the Berthana cn
Tuesday evening, November 20. The
ladies of this society are fast dispo
ing of the tickets for the biggest social
affair of the season, which this ye

will be of a patriotic nature
0: Ks O:;GEUB;

Members of the O. K. O. club were
entertained by Miss Elsie Stone at her
home on Brinker avenue last Wednes-
day evening. The time was pleasant

ly spent in sewing and music after
which Miss Stohe served refreshments
to the following members present:

Misses Francis Goddard, Natalie Disc,
Laura Stoddard, Ethel Vaughn, Ber-
nice Vaughn, Marguerite Clark, Win
nie Smith, Winifred Huchinson, Carrie
Van Buskirk, and Cora Smith.

The club will meet again on Monday
with Mrs. Huchinson, 2645 Fowler

Mrs. Willem Jeffers was a wel-|
come guest in Ogden for several days!
during the week, on her return to Oma- |!
ha from Salt Lake City, where she at-
tended the annual banquet of St.
Mary’s aluminae, which took place last
Saturday evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Morgan But-
ler of Pocatello, Ida., spent Tuesday
in Ogden visiting Mrs. Butler's sister, |
Martha Shields.

Bernard Bauchman left Sunday night
for Idaho Falls on a business trip. He
expects to be away several weeks.

FAREWELL PARTY,
One of the pretty events of the week
in social circles was the farewell sur-
| prise party tendered Miss Thelma Bur-

| and spent a delightful evening in dance

AT THE CONSERVATORY.
A number of the pupils of Squire
oop gave a studio recital yesterday
afternoon in the Ogden Conservatory
of Music. The selections were excep-

Mrs. Charles Fisher was called to|Uonally difficult and were given in an
New York City by the sudden death| excellent manner as [ollows:

In a letter received by the Knights
of Columbus from “Somewhere in
France,” A. L. La Franiere, a member
of coancil 777, highly commends the
benefits the soldiers are receiving from
the generosity of the Knights of Co-
lumbus war fund.

Mr, and Mrs. & A. Moss‘ have re-
turned home after spending six weeks
in the eastern states.

Mrs. D. Seerey and Mrs. J. Boyle,
who are in charge of the Red Cross
Christmas boxes, presented the Ogden
chapter with fifty boxes. Miss Daisy
Maginnis, representative of the Chil-
dren of Mary, donated twenty-four.

All information relative to the Red
Cross knitting work may be procured
from Mrs. Mary Connor at 210 Twen-
ty-third atreet. The gauze department
is in charge of Mrs. Raymond P. Mor-
rissey at 860 Twenty-seventh street.

The Junior class of the conservatory
gave a recital at the rooms this after-
noon which was enjoyed by quite a
number of the parents and interested
friends. The following played: Doro-
thy Higginbotham, Virgina Neuteboom,
Edith Halverson, Bessie Naisbitt,
Gladys Norton, Falck, Pearl Kinman,
Bertha Eccles, Ruth Nelson, Sterling
Scoville, Virginia Green, Vina Rich-
mond, Opal Farnlund, Aura Flowers,
Ruth Brewer, Frances Beemer and
Frances Pedler. A Hallowe'en party
will be given at the Conservatory late
this afternoon for the Junior class fol-
lowing their recital.

| FOR MISS DORA SMITH,
Mrs. I. L. Howes and Miss Louise
Pierce entertained Miss Dora Smith
delightful goodbye party at

home ef Miss Pierce on Tuesday last
Che decorations were appropriate to
the season and the dining room was a
bower of beauty. Covers were laid for
sixteen. The guest of honor received |
as a souvenir of her friends’ wit and
ilent clever booklet of original
wishes and drawings which was great-
ly enjoyed by all. Miss Smith is one
of Ogden’s most talented violinists and

MISS |ADWIE

An extensive campaign for conser-
vation of sugar |s to be started in We

| home economics demonstrator for the

‘county, in response to requests from
/the government that sugar ba saved,
its use lessened and general economy)
instituted.

country is faced with a serious sugar

Utopia Club,

Mrs. John W. Scowcroft was _ hos- |
tess to the Utopia club at her home
on Jackson avenue yesterday after-
noon, The ladies _ brought their
needlework and sewed and chatted
;during the afternoon Mrs Scow-
croft served a dainty luncheon In
,addition to the club members pres
isent, two guests enjoyed the after
|noon, They were Mrs. W. W. Brown
jing and Mrs. Jack Majo The club
will meet again in two weeks with
Mrs. W. E. Wymer at her home,
12158 Harrison avenue

Vincent Chautauqua Circle
| The meeting of the Vincent Chau-
jtauqua circle was especially enter
taining and instructive on Friday
lafternoon of this week when the
ltextbook under discussion, “‘Charac-
ters and Evenis in Roman History,”
iby Guglielmo Ferrero, was divided
}into sections and handled as follows:

“Corruption in Ancient Rome,”
Mrs. David Jensen

| Maude Green

| Georginia Marriott
| “Nero,” Miss Arthelia Mathis

OF THE WEEK
i J

| Very popular are the juniors at Sa-
cred Heart, for again they have shown
their marvelous capability for enter-
taining On Wednesday, October 31,

before entering the dining room where
a dainty Hallowe'en supper awaited
them, the seniors were presented with
programs meade by the artistic juniors
50 much did the original folders prom-
ise that the girls could hardly wait to
|reach the gymnasium. On entering the
| pretty little hall they were confident
that if the plans for their entertain-
ment were as well carried out as had
been the decorative scheme, the
evening was certain to be a delightful

one, and they were not disappointed.
After two happy hours of dancing the
(girls were served delicious refresh
ments. Still another surprise was in

store for them, when the juniors an-
nounced that they would vote for the
best senior. Their decision would
prove that Miss Frances McCormick
must be very good to the little girls.
They then decided that the most pop-
ular senior was Loretta Richie. Mil-
dred Miles was declared by the older

girls to be the most popular junior
Father Sullivan, who thoughtfully

looked in upon the fun, added much
pleasure to the occasion by his pres.
ence The’ oldest senior, and the
youngest minim were equally happy,

and even the juniors were not too busy |
| the party dispersed, refreshments were entertaining to thoroughly enjoy them-
| served,
| selves.

| Last week brought the conclusion of
|}the October devotions, which have|
| been most faithfully attended. How-
ever, the girls of Sacred Heart are not
spasmodic Christians, delighting only
in special kinds of devotions, but with
the same zeal with which they haa
said the Rosary, they started the
\of a

well seasoned with the democratic
spirit of Chattauqua, was delightfully

Child Culture Club.

The Child Culture club will meet
| Thursday next at the home of the Uni
jversity club on Washington avenue
and Twenty-sixth street, with Mrs
Farr, Mrs. Henry Gwilliam and Mrs
Frank Tribe as hostesses.
Ladies’ Literary Club.

The Ladies Literary club will meet
on Wednesday afternoon, November 14,
at the home of Mrs. R. B. Porter, on
)}North Washington avenue. Mrs. Por-
}ter will entertain the members at a
jluncheon at 1 o’clock and the regular
meeting will follow.

The first real activity of the newly
organized University club will be on

will be held in the attractive club
rooms of the Heywood building, corner
of Washington avenue and Twenty
sixth street. It will be in the nature
“get-together” affair. Light re-
freshments will be served and enter-
tainment will be provided. It will start

; month of November by receiving Com.
munion for the holy souls, and mak-
ing countless visits to the chapel dur.
|} ing the days of special grace,

Father Lagan, who has been visiting
|/in Bureka, was joyfully received at
Sacred Heart and on November 1 he
celebraied his three Masses in the
academy chapel,

Scarcely a week has passed that did |
not hold some fortunate surprise for |
the fortunate graduates. Last Sun-!
day, on returning from their afternoon
walk, the favored girls found Father
Lagan and Father Sullivan waiting to
take them for a ride in the Hupmobile
Through the kindness of these ever-
thoughtful friends, the class had the
pleasure of seeing Ogden canyon jn all
its autumnal glory, and came back for

The class of '18 is rejoicing in the
satisfaction that two months of work
are successfully finished. The girls
attaining the highest averages in their
mental philosophy, literature, astrono.
my, history and English are Aletha
Hunter, Inez Allen and Katherine Ki)-
liher,

On Friday afternoon the second aca-
demics thoroughly reviewed their Eng-
lish literature in a successful test. The
eirls especially deserving of credit are |
Margery Mullen, Thelma Parsons,
Pauline Sparks and Hazel Abbey,

Se Las eee ‘
The beginners in the business

course took their first test in ghort- |
hand during the week, and the Misses |
Jessie Fulmer and §stelle Covert
were most successful.

On Tuesday evening the third aca-
demics, anxious to do’ something for
Mother Pauline’s entertainment, gave
@ most thorough and artistic presen-
tation of Ben Hur, with the aid of |
stereopticon views of the Play, Each
member of the class told a portion of
the story in a manner highly credita-
hJe to the young ladt{es, considering
the difficulties of extemporaneous
neaking, and the fact that this was
heir first public appearance as a
class, The kindly guest of honor was
at 8 o'clock. Attorney Samuel C. Pow-
ell is the chairman of the entertain-|
ment committee.
MISS FOX HOSTESS

Miss Maxine Fox entertained a num-
ber of little people Thursday evening
at her home, 2546 Fowler avenue, be-
tween the hours of 3 to 6. The occa
sion was her own and Master Charles
Hetzel's fifth birthdays Mrs. J. G
Leonard, Mrs. C. C. Hetzel and Mrs.
Ralph Roberts assisted Mrs. Fox with
games and amusements, while Claudia
Roberts, Hope Fox and Miss Gertia
Woodruff, domestic science instructor
of the Ogden high school, had charge
of the luncheon The color scheme
was pink and white. Those present

SURPRISE PARTY FOR MRS.
TURNER,
evening, November 4
On Monday

the Royal Neighbors of America had
|a surprise on Mrs. A. L. Turner at
| her home on Canyon road, where

forty Royal Neighbors desired admit-
ltance. After being admitted, cards
| were played and honors were awarded
to Mrs. Granquist, Mrs Rall, Mrs. Zim-
merman, Trace, Turner and Lee
Goucher. After the honors were given

| Mrs. Turner was presented with a
| beautiful cut glass flower basket in
remembrance of her birthday. Re
freshments were served. Music and
singing wre furnished by Miss
| Turner, Miss McFarlane, Mr, Day and
| Mr. Querry. All departed with a!
smile.

QUEEN ESTHER CHAPTER O, EE, S
Members of Queen Esther Chapter

No. 4, O. BE. S., will give an afternoon
tea in the Masonic temple next

Wednesday afternoon when Red Cross
knitting will be the afternoon's diver-
sion. A splendid program of literary
and musical numbers will be given and
refreshments will be served. The sil
ver offering will be added to the fund
for flowers and for the care of
the sick. Mrs. J. G. Falck will
chairman of this meeting

| HOME FROM HONEYMOON TRIP

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Wright
have returned from their honeymoon
trip to California where the: visited
for the past three weeks in Los
geles with the bride's sister, Mrs. R.
Farley and in San Francisco with an-
} other sister, Mrs. A. W. Cooley The
| various points of interest throughout
the state were visited by the happy
couple who are now at home in the

AT O. H. S. LAST WEDNESDAY.

GRATITUDE’S OFFERING.
A Song of Thanksgiving and Love,
Autumn dances through the wood-
lands, }
Weaves a charm on distant hills, |
Throws a veil across the mountains
And a song of triumph trills.

Blue or gray her eyes, we know not;
In their depths a mystic light
Half recalls the Spring-days’ promise—
Halt portenas the Winter's night. |

Through her tears she smiles in glad-
ness
And her smiles fade into tears:
For she knows the past and future,
While she sings their hopes and!
fears.

Autumn crows the year with beauty,
Paints the woods with sunset’s
glow;
Lights her torch with golden splendor.
Where the morning-star burns low.

Then she floods the earth with sun-
shine,
Turns the Summer's green to gold;
Rocks to sleep thy baby leaf-buds—
